title: Citi, ADRI and MEIC Launch Seventh Annual Microentrepreneurship Awards in Costa Rica
summary: San José, Costa Rica - Citi, the Citi Foundation, the ADRI Association and MEIC announced the opening of nominations for the seventh annual Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards in Costa Rica.
tag-1: Citi, ADRI and MEIC Launch Seventh Annual Microentrepreneurship Awards in Costa Rica
tag-3: San José, Costa Rica – Citi, the Citi Foundation, the ADRI Association and MEIC announced the opening of nominations for the seventh annual Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards in Costa Rica.
tag-4: The Minister of Economics, Industry and Commerce, Mayi Antillón and representatives of participating Microcredit Lending Institutions and Business Development Service Providers were present at the launch event for the awards, the purpose of which is to recognize the important role microenterprise plays in the growth of the Costa Rican economy. The awards also seek to encourage and promote microfinance as a tool for development and reducing poverty. The competition highlights the careers of successful microentrepreneurs as models for other small business owners to emulate.
tag-5: "For the Ministry of Economics, Industry and Commerce, which oversees the country's SMEs [small and medium enterprises], this type of program is vitally important for motivating all of those entrepreneurs who do good work but who, for reasons out of their control, often do not have access to bank financing," Antillón remarked. "We have identified partnerships between the public and private sectors and NGOs as the best strategy for promoting SMEs. We are committed to this country's entrepreneurs, and so we can't help but applaud and support this great initiative."
tag-6: To date, around 100 microentrepreneurs from around the country have participated in each of the previous annual competitions, and more than 40 have received awards totaling in excess of US$100,000. "The winners have used the cash prizes to pay off loans, invest in tools for their businesses and improve their homes and household living conditions," said Juan Pablo Montoya, ADRI's General Manager.
tag-7: The winners of the 2012 Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards, such as doña Roena Enelda Brown Down, who owns a restaurant specializing in Caribbean food in Limón; or doña Johana Morris Jones, winner of the award for best Woman Microentrepreneur, were chosen for their ability to overcome adversity and their dedication to their businesses' development.
tag-8: "This award is our flagship corporate social responsibility project in Costa Rica and many of the countries where we maintain a presence," noted Marcelo Gorrini, Costa Rica Citi Country Officer. "This year, Citi marks 45 years of uninterrupted presence in Costa Rica. We are proud to say that we haven't stopped working for the community in any of those years. The awards have been expanded this year to offer more benefits to the winners, and MEIC's support is a sign of the initiative's importance for the country."
tag-10: Microentrepreneurs who would like to be considered for the awards must be nominated by Associations, Foundations, Chambers of Commerce, Solidarity Associations, Savings and Loan Coops, or any other institution that supports small businesses. Nominations will also be accepted from State or Private Commercial Banks with micro-financing programs. Only these institutions may nominate microentrepreneurs who meet the prerequisites to participate.
tag-11: Registration is free for all microentrepreneurs who are Costa Rican citizens or reside in this country. All microenterprises nominated by financial institutions must be registered with MEIC as an SME or be in the process of registering. For the definition of an SME, please consult the general rules contained in Law 8262 for Strengthening Small and Medium-Sized Businesses. Participating microentrepreneurs must be Costa Rican or naturalized citizens and have at least four years of proven experience operating their business. They must have been active clients of the institution nominating them for at least two years.
tag-12: This year's award categories are Commerce, Services, Industry, Woman Entrepreneurs and Most Environmentally Friendly Business.
tag-13: Nominations will be received at the ADRI Association offices until 4 p.m. on Friday, October 4, 2013. The address is Asociación ADRI De Plaza Mayor, 225 m al sur, Frente del Parqueo del ICE, Rohrmorser, San José, Costa Rica. Attention: Juan Pablo Montoya Vargas, General Manager.
tag-14: Judging Committee To maintain the awards' high standards, final decisions are made by a specialized Judging Committee made up of representatives of the Ministry of Economics and Commerce, the national microfinance network, academia, the private sector and Citi Costa Rica executives.
tag-15: For more information about the awards, please visit the ADRI Association website: www.adricr.com www.adri.co.cr.
tag-16: The Citi Foundation The Citi Foundation is committed to the economic empowerment and financial inclusion of individuals and families, particularly those in need, in the communities where we work so that they can improve their standard of living. Globally, the Citi Foundation targets its strategic giving to priority focus areas: Microfinance, Enterprise Development, Youth Education and Livelihoods, and Financial Capability and Asset Building. The Citi Foundation works with its partners in Microfinance and Enterprise Development to support environmental programs and innovations. Additional information can be found at www.citifoundation.com.

Citi provides consumers, corporations, governments and institutions with a broad range of financial products and services, including consumer banking and credit, corporate and investment banking, securities brokerage, transaction services, and wealth management.

tag-19: ADRI With 26 years of experience in serving the micro, small and medium enterprise sector in Costa Rica, ADRI is a leading resource for businesses that operate in this sector in the country. ADRI serves the entire country with headquarters in Rohrmorser, San José Province. Our seven branches in San José, Limón, Siquirres, Guápiles, Jacó, Pérez Zeledón and Ciudad Neily allow us to provide timely, creative and personalized financial services to strengthen, grow and develop businesses at the national level, maximizing operating efficiency and efficacy. tag-20: The Ministry of Economics, Industry and Commerce The Ministry of Economics, Industry and Commerce (MEIC) has a legal mandate to oversee public policies designed to promote private enterprise and business culture in accordance with the functions enumerated in the Constitution and laws and decrees concerning SMEs. According to the Organic Law of the Ministry of Economics, Industry and Commerce, Law 6054, Article 2, the Ministry of Economics, Industry and Commerce shall have maximum authority in formulating and overseeing the execution of business policy, especially with regard to SMES. To this end, it is authorized to establish the most appropriate form of internal organization for pursuing this mission and the best means of coordination with both public and private sector institutions, with the goal of improving the effectiveness of the support programs they run. For more information, please visit: www.meic.go.cr.
